options.label: A
options.text: Normal heart sounds in all horses

options.label: B
options.text: Prolonged audible vibrations developing in a usually quiet portion of the cardiac cycle

questions.explanation: Cardiac murmurs are prolonged audible vibrations developing in a usually quiet portion of the cardiac cycle. They are not normal heart sounds (A), always pathologic (C), or only heard in foals (D).

questions.stem: Cardiac murmurs can be manifestations of:

options.label: B
options.text: Either normal (functional) or abnormal (pathologic) blood flow

questions.explanation: Cardiac murmurs can be manifestations of either normal (functional) or abnormal (pathologic) blood flow. Only abnormal (A), only normal (C), or only congenital defects (D) are not accurate.

questions.stem: In horses, which additional heart sounds can normally be heard (not always pathological)?
questions.explanation: In horses, S3 and S4 can normally be heard (not always pathological). S1 and S2 only (A), only S1 (C), or no additional sounds (D) are not accurate.

options.label: B
options.text: Vibrations from rapid ejection of large volume of blood or large inflow into ventricles

questions.explanation: Physiologic murmurs are caused by vibrations from rapid ejection of large volume of blood or large inflow into ventricles. Valvular dysfunction (A), congenital defects (C), or infection (D) cause pathologic murmurs.

options.label: B
options.text: Acquired valvular dysfunction or congenital cardiac malformations

questions.explanation: Pathologic murmurs are caused by acquired valvular dysfunction or congenital cardiac malformations. Only congenital (A), only functional flow (C), or normal aging (D) are not complete.

questions.stem: Heart murmurs are characterized by all of the following EXCEPT:

options.label: C
options.text: Shape and point of maximal intensity

questions.explanation: Color is not used to characterize heart murmurs. Timing and duration (A), quality and radiation (B), and shape and PMI (C) are used.

options.label: A
options.text: Very loud, radiating over widespread area

options.label: C
options.text: Very quiet, only heard over a very localized area after careful auscultation

questions.explanation: Grade I murmurs are very quiet, only heard over a very localized area after careful auscultation in quiet environment, may be inconsistent. Very loud (A), moderately loud (B), or loud (D) describe higher grades.

options.label: B
options.text: Extremely loud, also heard with the stethoscope held just above the skin surface

questions.explanation: Grade VI murmurs are extremely loud, also heard with the stethoscope held just above the skin surface. Very quiet (A), moderately loud (C), or quiet (D) describe lower grades.

options.label: B
options.text: A common valvular issue causing reduced performance

questions.explanation: Mitral valve regurgitation is a common valvular issue causing reduced performance. It is not rare (A), only seen in foals (C), or always fatal (D).

options.label: A
options.text: Strong breed, age, and sex predisposition

options.label: B
options.text: No breed, age, or sex predisposition; rare in foals/yearlings

questions.explanation: Mitral valve regurgitation has no breed, age, or sex predisposition; rare in foals/yearlings. Strong predisposition (A), only Thoroughbreds (C), or only older horses (D) are not accurate.

questions.stem: The point of maximal intensity (PMI) for mitral valve regurgitation is:

options.label: B
options.text: Mitral area, radiates dorsally to aortic area

questions.explanation: The PMI for mitral valve regurgitation is the mitral area, radiates dorsally to aortic area. Aortic area (A), pulmonic area (C), or tricuspid area (D) are not correct.

options.label: B
options.text: The most commonly detected cardiac murmur in racehorses

questions.explanation: Tricuspid valve regurgitation (TR) is the most commonly detected cardiac murmur in racehorses. It is not rarely detected (A), always pathologic (C), or only seen in foals (D).

options.label: B
options.text: Clinically insignificant, even in severe cases

questions.explanation: Tricuspid valve regurgitation is usually clinically insignificant, even in severe cases. Always significant (A), fatal (C), or requiring surgery (D) are not accurate.

questions.stem: Ventricular septal defect (VSD) is seen more frequently in:

options.label: B
options.text: Arabian horses and Welsh Mountain Ponies

questions.explanation: VSD is seen more frequently in Arabian horses and Welsh Mountain Ponies (possible genetic basis). Thoroughbreds only (A), all breeds equally (C), or only foals (D) are not accurate.

options.label: B
options.text: Left-to-right shunting of blood from left ventricle to right ventricle

questions.explanation: VSD involves left-to-right shunting of blood from left ventricle to right ventricle. Right-to-left (A), no shunting (C), or bidirectional (D) are not typical.
Large VSDs can cause heart failure. No clinical signs (A), only mild exercise intolerance (C), or complete recovery (D) are not accurate for large defects.

questions.stem: Aortic regurgitation is most common in:

options.label: B
options.text: Older horses; the aortic valve is most frequently affected

questions.explanation: Aortic regurgitation is most common in older horses; the aortic valve is most frequently affected. Young horses (A), foals only (C), or all ages equally (D) are not accurate.

options.label: B
options.text: Degenerative changes (fibrous or nodular thickening of valve leaflets) or aortic valve prolapse secondary to VSD

questions.explanation: Aortic regurgitation is caused by degenerative changes (fibrous or nodular thickening of valve leaflets) or aortic valve prolapse secondary to VSD. Only congenital (A), infection only (C), or trauma only (D) are not complete.

questions.stem: Aortic regurgitation murmur character is often:
questions.explanation: Aortic regurgitation murmur character is often decrescendo and musical (classic AR sound). Harsh and continuous (A), only systolic (C), or not audible (D) are not accurate.

options.label: B
options.text: Wide pulse pressure with "bounding" or "waterhammer" pulse

questions.explanation: Aortic regurgitation can result in wide pulse pressure with "bounding" or "waterhammer" pulse. Narrow pulse pressure (A), no pulse changes (C), or irregular pulse only (D) are not accurate.

options.label: B
options.text: Commonly identified through Doppler echocardiography, rarely detected by auscultation

questions.explanation: Pulmonary valve regurgitation is commonly identified through Doppler echocardiography, rarely detected by auscultation. Commonly detected by auscultation (A), always audible (C), or always pathologic (D) are not accurate.
Pulmonary valve regurgitation is usually clinically insignificant; rarely causes symptoms. Clinically significant (A), always fatal (C), or requiring treatment (D) are not accurate.

options.label: B
options.text: Infection of the endocardial surface of the heart, usually involving valves

questions.explanation: Endocarditis is infection of the endocardial surface of the heart, usually involving valves. Epicardium (A), myocardium only (C), or not infectious (D) are not accurate.

options.label: B
options.text: Bacterial colonization of endocardium during bacteremia

questions.explanation: Endocarditis is caused by bacterial colonization of endocardium during bacteremia. Viral only (A), fungal only (C), or parasitic (D) are not typical causes.

questions.stem: Clinical signs of endocarditis include all of the following EXCEPT:
questions.explanation: Profuse diarrhea is not a typical clinical sign of endocarditis. Fever (A), weight loss and depression (B), and intermittent lameness (C) are typical signs.

options.label: B
options.text: Positive blood culture and echocardiography to visualize vegetative lesions

questions.explanation: Definitive diagnosis of endocarditis requires positive blood culture (to identify organism) and echocardiography (to visualize vegetative lesions). CBC only (A), radiography only (C), or serology only (D) are not definitive.
Treatment of endocarditis involves aggressive, long-term antibiotic therapy (5–6 weeks). Short-term (A), no antibiotics (C), or antivirals only (D) are not appropriate.

options.label: B
options.text: Guarded to poor, due to risk of embolic showering and potential for congestive heart failure

questions.explanation: The prognosis for endocarditis is guarded to poor, due to risk of embolic showering and potential for congestive heart failure. Always excellent (A), always good (C), or age only (D) are not accurate.

options.label: B
options.text: Mitral regurgitation, tricuspid regurgitation, VSD, aortic regurgitation, and endocarditis

questions.explanation: Echocardiography is essential for diagnosing mitral regurgitation, tricuspid regurgitation, VSD, aortic regurgitation, and endocarditis. Only VSD (A), only endocarditis (C), or only physiologic murmurs (D) are not accurate.
Small VSDs have good prognosis; normal performance likely. Poor prognosis (A), always require surgery (C), or always fatal (D) are not accurate for small defects.
